quote: Instead of aiming for a specific ranking, I decided to focus on experiencing the journey. Otherwise, I would have been anxious the whole time, unable to appreciate what I was doing... I told myself I just wanted to visit Europe by bike and reach the finish line in one piece.

After pushing harder in the Swiss mountains to improve my position in the race, I completely missed the first checkpoint! I was only 2 km away, fortunately, but issue after issue (dead phone, GPS coordinates pointing to the wrong placeâ€¦) I ended up losing an hour trying to find the Checkpoint 1 hote...

My highlights: The highest point was when I took the gravel road between 4a and 4b and looked back at everything I had climbed. The lowest point was on parcours 3, which seemed endless with the heat and the tough gravel for kilometers.

Last year seems like a warm-up ride for this year... I'm definitely feeling well prepared, but of course, there is a little bit of nervousness because there are so many things that can happen and there are new countries we have to ride through, so it will be very exciting.
I'm a little bit afraid of the number four Parcours in TÃ¼rkiye, the off-road section, because I'm always a little bit afraid of the off-road section.

It's my third really big race and last year was the very first attempt in actually going for a win in a major race. I think it just makes sense that now with the third attempt, chances are way higher than they have been last year.

I think there might be a few contenders for the first place, so I think it will be a big battle in the beginning. I think I have spent more time than the two previous years combined on making my route, maybe it's because I feel the pressure not to screw this up.

I always had it in my head that I'd like to do it again at some point. I thought either 10 years since I won it, which would be next year, or 10 years since I first did it... I haven't got any expectations.
To be honest, I don't feel super prepared, but I never do. I'm the least organised person. I think the more of these I do, the more relaxed I seem to get. It's probably not a good thing.
I feel quite comfortable to be in unsupported bike race mode because of doing the Atlas Mountain Race in February, then in May The Accursed, but this race is completely different.

I haven't spent a lot of time in the East of Europe, so I'm really looking forward to it. I hear the hospitality is amazing and the more East you go it gets more gnarly. I have no idea what to expect but I'm ready to explore and see everything when I'm racing.
If she [Fiona Kolbinger] can do it, so can I. That's how I live my life. If somebody else is out there doing it, I can do it too.
The TCR is not just a raceâ€”it's a journey that changes you. The mental challenge is just as tough as the physical one.
Despite the disappointment, the most important part is that I really did have an amazing two weeks or so, including riding to the start of the race, hurtling my way through 11 very distinct countries
Mainly a split between 4Season Disc and 4Season Gravel Disc with a few carbons and dynamos thrown in
For luggage, I fully trusted Apidura with their Expedition and Race series. 14L + 2L + 4L
Outside of the bikes and wheels, we were surprised to see just how slimmed down rider's luggage set-ups are getting - a sure sign of how serious this epic event is becoming.

Clip-on aero bars are, of course, a must to have more position options and maintain comfort over long distances, in addition to being more aerodynamic and thus gaining a bit of speed and/or saving more energy depending on how you see the situation ðŸ˜‰
I had a few equipment adjustments, such as a tool bag that fell off and a 3D-printed mount for my Garmin Varia that gave way under the vibrations of the Flemish cobblestones.

For sleeping, for example, I opted for a lightweight and compact down jacket to replace a sleeping bag, reducing both weight and volume. The jacket could also be used for really cold days on the bike.

We've experienced the effects of climate-related extreme weather events first-hand in our Racing grounds, with severe flooding in Slovenia putting riders at risk while raging heatwaves in the south of Europe exacerbated riders' suffering on an already arduous route

The icy conditions came early in the journey, with the first control point taking riders to the heights of the Italian Alps and over some of the highest paved roads in the region to reach the Passo dello Spluga
Heading out of Roubaix, riders strike out for Geraardsbergen, the spiritual home of the TCR, via a Parcours composed of well-known cobbled climbs.
BjelaÅ¡nica awaits... riders will take a different track skirting below the summit â€“ representing the first off-road section of the Race.
This took riders to the Carinthian region, a place of rugged peaks and dense forests where the paved roads give way to rougher surfaces, sometimes gravel and sometimes rough-hewn rock.
Mangartsko Sedlo, a road with 17% gradients and a summit over 2000m high, offering riders uninterrupted views of the stunning Julian Alps
First control point taking riders to the heights of the Italian Alps and over some of the highest paved roads in the region to reach the Passo dello Spluga and registration in Livigno

I think I have spent more time than the two previous years combined on making my route, maybe it's because I feel the pressure not to screw this up. I want to do as well as I did last year, I want to be at the same level again.
After some route planning issues, which caused me to lose precious time on some tricky gravel roads within the first 500km
I'm going to use every single piece of experience and knowledge to do what I can

Mistakes are human, and they are part of the race. I told myself I just wanted to visit Europe by bike and reach the finish line in one piece. I had a lot to learn from this experience, which could be useful in other situations in my life.

There was a general shift for riders to be on more sturdy wheels this year. This is presumably because of the few gravel sections thrown in as well as the infamous off-road section from a few years ago which many rider's TCR was brought to an abrupt end.
The most difficult part was finding electrolytes once I reached the Balkans. I discovered a bit after the race that electrolytes are sometimes only sold in pharmacies.
I'm a little bit afraid of the number four Parcours in TÃ¼rkiye, the off-road section, because I'm always a little bit afraid of the off-road section.
Severe flooding in Slovenia putting riders at risk while raging heatwaves in the south of Europe exacerbated riders' suffering on an already arduous route
Outside of the bikes and wheels, we were surprised to see just how slimmed down rider's luggage set-ups are getting - a sure sign of how serious this epic event is becoming.

The TCR has been going on for ten years. It is still a niche event but it is getting bigger and attracting more media attention... The transcontinental race has been going for a few days now. This is the premier ultra-cycling event on the calendar.
The 40 women on the start line making it the largest women's field at a TCR ever
Lost Dot's 100Women campaign has attracted a record 79 to the startline
When I cycled around the world a few years ago, I went through Istanbul and stayed there for a few weeks and I absolutely loved it so I've always wanted to go back

Around 350 riders this year also faced mandatory gravel sections along the journey from the start on the unrelenting cobbled ascent of the Muur-Kepelmuur in Geraardsbergen on July 23 to Thessaloniki... with riders facing a shorter but more mountainous route in 2023.
Whilst the fastest charioteers could make a fortune, the fastest finishers of the Transcontinental will find no more and no less than those behind them: a warm embrace and a cold beer.
